subNodes.conversationText: root

The next morning, Grimes sets you down in the Blackwinter Docks as promised. The docks are heaving with men and elves looking for work on the moored ships.

"Some of the men are going to the Half Moon Tavern," he says. "When you're ready to depart you'll find me there."
"Make sure you're ready."

Grimes spits on the muddy ground. "We'll be ready. Just try not to get yourself killed in this cesspit - I don't fancy sharing the journey back with a corpse." 

He turns and pushes his way through the crowd.
Continue
"Excuse me. Are you <FullName>?"
"Yes."

"Pleased to meet you; I am Captain Brin. Lord Dorian asked me to meet you off the boat. Please follow me."

The guard winces slightly.

"And watch out for folk emptying chamber pots from windows. You don't want to meet Lord Dorian smelling of piss."
"Thanks for the advice. Lead the way."

The guard leads you briskly through the bustling streets. You find yourself gagging slightly on the overpowering smells of faeces and sweat and cover your nose and mouth with your cloak. You try not to think about what it is your boots are squelching through on the ground. 

All around you are signs of poverty and decay.
Continue

The guard notices your discomfort and snorts derisively. 

"You'll get used to it."
"I won't be here long enough, thank the gods."
"We'll see."
Continue

Captain Brin lets out a sudden exclamation of surprise and holds up his hand, bringing you to a stop.

The house in front of you is large and old, set back away from the street. It is surrounded by a high wall and a wrought iron gate. 

The gate is open, creaking in the wind. In front of it, two guards lie face down in their own blood.
"What the hell?"

Captain Brin draws his sword with a harsh metalic rasp. 

"Lord Dorian's house is under attack! They must have come to rescue the Baron. Come with me!"
[Draw your weapon] "Lead on."
"Perhaps I'm just less callous than you."
"Compassion will get you killed."
"We'll see."

Captain Brin lets out a sudden exclamation of surprise and holds up his hand, bringing you to a stop.

The house in front of you is large and old, set back away from the street. It is surrounded by a high wall and a wrought iron gate. 

The gate is open, creaking in the wind. In front of it, two guards lie face down in their own blood.
"This place really is a total hole."

The guard leads you briskly through the bustling streets. You find yourself gagging slightly on the overpowering smells of faeces and sweat and cover your nose and mouth with your cloak. You try not to think about what it is your boots are squelching through on the ground. 

All around you are signs of poverty and decay.
"Who are you?"
"Not that it matters, but I'm Captain Brin of the City Watch. I'm under instruction from Lord Dorian to meet <FullName> at the docks this morning. You match the description. So is it you or not?"
"I am <FullName>."

"Very well. Follow me."

Captain Brin winces slightly.

"And please, watch out for folk emptying chamber pots from windows. You don't want to meet Lord Dorian smelling of piss."
"Thanks for the advice. Lead the way."

The guard leads you briskly through the bustling streets. You find yourself gagging slightly on the overpowering smells of faeces and sweat and cover your nose and mouth with your cloak. You try not to think about what it is your boots are squelching through on the ground. 

All around you are signs of poverty and decay.
"This place really is a total hole"

The door opens and you step into a long corridor decorated with colourful tapestries and paintings.

The guard snorts derisively at the path of muddy bootprints you are leaving on the carpet and shuts the main door behind you.

"He's not going to like that."
"I don't care."

The guard leads you to a large living room in the house, richly decorated with heavy tapestries and a cracking fire in the stone wall. 

A man in a green robe rises from his comfortable chair.
Continue

"Ah, you must be <FullName>."

"Thank you Captain Brin. You may leave us."
Continue

"Yes, Lord Dorian."

"Good luck, <FullName>. We will meet again."
Continue
Dorian waits for Captain Brin to leave the room, and gestures for you to sit down.
"And who are you, exactly?"

"My name is Ser Dorian. I am the Seneschal of Blackwinter, responsible for the day to day running of the city. I should have met you from your boat at the docks of course, but I'm afraid that this morning there have been... complications. Difficulties."

"In fact, I'm rather afraid that I have somewhat... bad news. For you."
"What do you mean?"
"I'm afraid Baron Kelbor has escaped."
"What! How did you let this happen?!"

Dorian looks pained.

"Yes, well. I don't think I would quite say that we 'let' it happen. Not exactly. The prisoner was being moved to the barracks in preparation for being handed over to you. I don't know what happened, but I'm told that the guards were slaughtered in the street and there is no sign of your Baron."
"He was rescued? Who knew he was even here?"

"We were discreet, of course. He was registered in a false name. But I'm afraid that the walls are very thin in this city. I couldn't guarantee that the secret wasn't, in fact, actually quite well known."
"This is completely unacceptable. The Lord Chancellor will hear of this."
"Yes, he will, won't he? I'm rather afraid we're both in trouble there, <FullName>. I certainly have no desire to be dragged back to the King and... punished. I'm sure you feel the same way."
"Me? I can hardly be held to blame for your mistake!"

"Well, no. To be sure. But I rather imagine that Lord Chancellor Cromnor will still expect you to find this Baron and bring him back, yes? If you return empty handed, I rather suspect the Lord Chancellor will lack interest in the details of your failure."

"I think that means we have a shared problem."
"So what do you propose?"

"That we find your prisoner again, of course! I doubt Cromnor will give a rat's ass about our little provincial problems as long as he gets his man. A delay can be explained. He might even find it amusing. As long as we deliver him his prisoner!"
"I agree. We need to find Baron Kelbor."
"No doubt you have questions."
"When did this happen?"
"This morning. Just before you came ashore, in fact. We had been holding the Baron at Castle Lor and were moving him to the local garrison for collection."
Continue
"Did the Baron say anything whilst he was in custody?"

"Not to me, certainly. I had no wish to speak to him. Sometimes one can accidentally hear things that one comes to regret, and I have no interest in being caught up in the politics of the King's court, <FullName>."
"Might he have spoken to anyone else?"

"It's possible. He was kept mainly in solitary confinement and gagged. But I didn't watch him twenty four hours a day. I can't guarantee that people weren't getting messages to him somehow. Perhaps you should speak to his gaolor."
"Maybe I will."
"Any suggestions about where to start looking?"

"He may still be in the city. Perhaps he has found a place to hide. But my guards are searching for him, and he has a price on his head that would tempt all but his closest friends... no, he will find hiding in the city difficult, I think. If I was him I would look to get him out of Blackwinter as quickly as possible."
"Go on."

"If he gets out of the city then finding him may become more difficult. The forests here are old and have many hiding places, and there are caves in the hills that have never been fully explored."

"I don't really see either as a good option. The forests are home to bandits, and the hills are crawling with orcs and worse."

"But then, I am not a desparate man."
"Could he be in league with the bandits?"

"It's possible. You may need to find out using your own methods."

"There are others that would also like to see havoc in the city. A new cult has sprung up recently calling themselves the Ettin. Their goals are unclear but they are very clearly not in the best interests of the city. And I have also heard rumours of dark clerics and druids massing in the Raventhal for some unknown reason."
"Go on."

"I have already instructed the Guild to look into these issues and made suitable rewards available."

"If you wish to investigate such problems during your hunt, I suggest you call into the Guild and ask some questions of them before setting out into the wilderness."
"Maybe I should check in with the Guild."
"Who might have known that he was being held captive here?"
"The castle gaolor, although he knew him by a different name. Myself. Captain Brin. Possibly some of the other castle staff or the guards may have recognised him. I don't know."
Continue
"What can you tell me about the ambush?"
"I'm told it was professional and ruthless. None of the guards survived, and none of the attackers were left behind."
"Were there any clues?"

"No witnesses, if that is what you mean. The closest things we have to clues are red blood on a guard's sword, suggesting that the attackers were human...or at least not orcs or lizardfolk. We also found some coarse brown fabric, possibly from a piece of clothing ripped during the fight. And that, my friend, is it."
Continue
"I think I've heard enough. How can you help me find him?"
"What is it you want?"
"I need a small team to help me track him down."

"My city guards are hunting him now. I have alerted those outside of the city to watch for him also. But I can't spare you fighters - we have lost too many to the orcs, and we have a real and imminent problem with a local cult. I need them here."
"That's not good enough, Dorian."
"I cannot offer you fighers. If you need companions, speak to the Guild. There is a generous bounty out on Kelbor, I'm sure some of their members would be pleased to help."
"Very well."
"That's it? That's the best you can do, telling me to hire mercenaries?"

"As I said, I have placed a generous bounty on Kelbor to be captured alive. I am not telling you to hire mercenaries with your own gold. The gold is already on offer, they just need to work with you to collect it."
"Very well, Dorian."
"I require gold and resources."

Dorian looks slightly pained.

"I have already given you all the gold I can spare, <FullName>. Please do not ask for any more."
"You can't blame me for trying."

"Of course. I imagine that you haven't come to Blackwinter prepared to mount an expedition. I'm afraid the city is far from rich though. You may have noticed the starving peasants in the streets? This is not by design - if I could fix it, I would. But the crops have failed for the second year in succession and the bandit raids have made merchants scared to travel here."

"Take this bag of gold. 150 pieces should be more than sufficient to buy weapons and armour and whatever you need for your hunt."
"150 gold pieces? I need more than that to track this Baron, Dorian."

"I suppose so."

Dorian sighs.

"Very well. 300 gold pieces. But that is all I can give you. I could fund a guard captain for six months for 300 gold. I can't spare any more."
"Very well."
"Thank you."
"That will do fine. Thank you."
"I want to be in overall charge of the hunt."
"I cannot allow that. Captain Brin will be in overall charge. He is a good man and has my full confidence. I will ask that he shares any information with you as soon as he has it."
"Cannot allow that? It wasn't a request, Dorian."

"Please, <FullName>. You must understand the delicate balance of power in the city. Captain Brin is extremely capable and will lead the search. Your own activities will be completely separate, of course."

"You must see. If you take over the search, it will look like the King is making a powerplay in Blackwinter. It must be a local man, to avoid... tensions."
"Are you refusing my request?"
"On this matter, yes. I'm afraid so."
"Cromnor will hear of this."
"Yes, I'm sure he will. But my position stands."
"Very well."
"Very well."
"Very well."
"Captain Brin seems like a good man. Very well."
"I need nothing else from you"

"Then I wish you luck with your hunt, <FullName>. You will find me at Castle Lor if you have further questions. Captain Brin will be present at the City Gate and will be given orders to keep you updated on the guard's progress."
[Nod and leave]
"Oh, and <FullName>? Please, next time clean the mud off your boots before entering my home."
Continue.
You leave Dorian alone with his thoughts.
Continue
"May the gods watch over us. We must find this Baron, Dorian." [Leave]

"Yes, or course."

"Oh, and <FullName>? Please, next time clean the mud off your boots before entering my home."
Continue
You leave Dorian alone with his thoughts.
Continue

"Then I wish you luck with your hunt, <FullName>. You will find me at Castle Lor if you have further questions. Captain Brin will be present at the City Gate and will be given orders to keep you updated on the guard's progress."

"I suggest you begin by speaking to the Guild. I have already instructed them to look into several developing issues around Blackwinter that may be connected to this."
"Very well. I will talk to them."
"Oh, and <FullName>? Please, next time clean the mud off your boots before entering my home."
Continue
You leave Dorian alone with his thoughts.
Continue
"I do things my way, Dorian. Not yours."

"Yes, or course."

"Oh, and <FullName>? Please, next time clean the mud off your boots before entering my home."
Continue
You leave Dorian along with his thoughts.
Continue
"Don't make the mistake of thinking we're on the same side, Dorian. But you're right, we have to find the Baron."
"What? Oh, dear, what a mess! You can clean it up later eh."
"You would do well to make friends in this city, <FullName>. Not enemies."
Continue.
[Shrug]
